OtherDetails:
This volume is the first book-length treatment of model-based geostatistics which refers to the application of general statistical principles of modelling and inference to geostatistical problems. The authors have written an expository text, emphasising statistical methods and applications. Analyses of data-sets from a range of scientific contexts feature prominently, and simulations are used to illustrate theoretical results. The computational results in the book are supported by the authors' R-based software package, geoR, whose usage is illustrated in a computational section at the end of each chapter.

The research contents compiles and presents in a comprehensive way work done by the authors in the field with emphasis on a model-based approach to geostatistics, including Bayesian inference, expanding the linear geostatistical model to the framework of generalized linear models and geostatistical design. Also is shown how the geostatistical model can be use as a component in more general modelling strategies. The book's methodological novelty is particularly contained in Chapters 4, 6, 7 and 8.

OtherDetails:
This monograph sets out a body of mathematical theory, for a finite graph G with n nodes placed randomly in Euclidean d-space and edges added to connect points that are r-close to each other, mainly asymptotics  with r(n) becoming small as n grows.  The relation to existing research is explained at the end of each chapter.  Chapters 3, 6, 7, 10, 11, and 13 contain  largely original results, some of which we highlight below.

Chapter 3: Given a finite graph H, depending on r(n), the number of copies (in G) of H can be asymptotically Poisson or normal. Likewise for the number of components of G isomorphic to H. Multivariate extensions hold, with formulae for limiting means and covariances.

Chapter 6: Two-point concentration for the distribution of the maximum degree in the subconnective regime; likewise for clique number. Laws of large numbers for maximum degree and clique number in the subconnective and connectivity regimes.

Chapter 7:  The (random) threshold value of r at which the minimum degree on n random points achieves value k, satisfies a law of large numbers when k(n) is fixed or grows logarithmically.

Chapters 10 and 11: In the subcritical thermodynamic limit, the largest component of G grows logarithmically with n; in the supercritical case, it grows like n, also satisfying a CLT, and the second-largest component grows like log n to the power d/(d-1). The RUNT test for bimodality is consistent.

Chapter 13: Strong law for the threshold for k-connectivity. Thresholds for  k-connectivity and for minimum degree k are equal with high probability. Normal limit for the number of components in thermodynamic limit.

This article has two main aims. One is to give a description of the complete prior elicitation process and associated issues, such as how to structure an elicitation session, feedback, overfitting, judging the quality of an assessed distribution, and whose opinion should be represented from a group elicitation. This overview partly reflects the authors? opinions and their considerable experience in developing, testing and using elicitation methods. The other aim is to review results from the psychology literature that are relevant to the development of elicitation methods and to provide a much closer link between these results and the design of elicitation methods than has been given before. Elicitation methods that have been proposed are reviewed and compared, and results from psychology are used to evaluate their strengths and identify their likely biases. 

This is the first review of this area for many years, undertaken by three of the leading international authorities on the topic. It provides a thorough and up-to-date practical grounding in the important, yet sometimes mysterious, problem of eliciting prior distributions for research studies. As such, the article is likely to be influential in a wide range of areas: although published only in mid-2005, it has already been cited in journals in medicine, health economics, physical chemistry, climate change, planetary science and pharmacy, as well as statistics.

LongTitle: The geometry of biplot scaling

OtherDetails:
This is the first research monograph published on the important topic of Procrustes analysis, on which Gower is a leading authority. Originating in factor matching problems, more recent developments arise from a growing number of fields of application, including the analysis of sensory data (the research area of the second author) and shape analysis. Procrustes problems are concerned with matching two or more sets of data under restricted linear transformations; the book focuses especially on orthogonal, projection, direction cosine matrices, as well as constrained affine transformations. The latter provide the best way of generalising canonical correlation analysis to several sets of variables. Theory, algorithms and applications are covered.

The book imposes a logical structure to, and unification of, results dispersed throughout a large literature. In so doing, several new research problems are identified and new solutions provided to old problems. Two of the six appendices ?A minimisation problem? and ?Symmetric matrix products? might be regarded as research papers in their own right. Solutions are provided to some, but not all, the new problems. Others have subsequently provided research topics and publications for Gower and collaborators; yet other problems still require development. Thus, the book contains a substantial research component and provides a foundation for further research.

This paper is a part of a concerted strategy to enhance the collaboration between the OR and AI research communities and to help define the future direction of research in the area of intelligent management systems in operations. This strategy involved organising European Conferences sponsored by the OR Society in 1997, 2001 and 2005. Subsequent conference proceedings and special issues of international journals were published (4 to date in addition to a special issue of JORS due to appear soon). This paper is the third of a series of reviews, the second of which was published in 2000 and was awarded the Literati Club Award. 

This survey deals with the decision problems in operations including manufacturing and service industries. OR researchers have traditionally studied the four major decision categories in operations, as identified by the authors, namely: Design, Scheduling, Process Planning & Control and Quality, Maintenance & Fault Diagnosis. Over 1200 publications are reviewed on AI applications in these areas.

The authors utilized a novel method to evaluate current trends and identify gaps in research. The publication rates were analysed against what we might have expected given the known characteristics of the techniques. Our view on application areas of the techniques was developed by positioning the various OR and AI techniques on a decision field i.e. decision level versus problem structure. 
   
The Survey confirms various trends, some that one might expect, and others that are less expected. It is noted that like OR, AI studies currently exhibit less emphasis on the important category of executive ill structured problems. Moreover, development of hybrid intelligent systems is identified as an area that requires research effort. The paper has been published in a major OR journal (JORS) in recognition of its expected impact on the OR field.

OtherDetails:
This book chapter is a full account of the modelling work carried out for the government of Sarawak, East Malaysia. Apart from the Final Report itself, presentation in this form allows a far fuller account than would be permitted with a journal article. It is the product of a major research project conducted over the period 2003-05 and is a novel application since the adoption of system dynamics modelling for macro-economic issues is in its infancy. However, the methodology has utility in this domain and the research serves as an example of a methodological counterpoint to the econometrics based projects commonly encountered.

The chapter stresses the importance of agreeing a purpose for the model with the clients. Here the purpose was one of managing a transition from a resource-based economy to a knowledge-based one. It meant that human resource development was a primary component of the analysis. (The human resource component has since spawned additional research both in Sarawak and the UK.) 

The model is described (with detail being given in an extensive appendix) and the behaviour arising from a number of specimen scenario runs, reflecting variants of possible policy options, is analysed. Additionally, some material is included which describes and reflects on an ?ease of use? shell (a microworld) which was developed in order to allow senior government officials (without the necessary software and modelling skills) to experiment with the model in their own time.

LongTitle: The Problem and Solutions in Using Delay Functions with Bifurcating Flows in System Dynamics Models
ShortTitle: Proceedings of the International Conference on Management Science & Engineering, Vol 1
OtherDetails:
This paper describes a mathematical adjustment it is necessary to make in order to avoid an error in a certain clearly-defined system dynamics (SD) model formulation.  This involves use of a delay in a resource flow, but in a situation where there are two outputs but only one input - a bifurcation in the flow.  (Examples are: patients moving from one disease state to a later one, but some die and take a side flow out; goods arriving into a warehouse and eventually being sold, but some perish or are pilfered and take a side flow out.)

The exponential delays often used to model the output from a stock are so commonly needed in SD modelling that software vendors routinely offer special library functions which facilitate their use.  They equate to the Erlang family of probability distributions, where a first-order delay is equivalent to an Erlang type 1 distribution (negative exponential delay profile), second-order relates to an Erlang type 2 and so on.  An infinite order delay has zero variance on output and merely reproduces the input but x time periods later.

When running a model of the epidemiology of HIV/AIDS for a very long time (one of a set of standard validity tests employed in SD modelling) we discovered that the flow was gaining mass.  An enhanced checksum equation in the model showed that the patient flows in and out over the run (allowing for those there at the start and at the end) were not equal and that a physical stock was going negative.  The discrepancy could be traced to the (appropriate) use of a DELAY function to model an output on an occasion where the flow bifurcated.  The paper describes the mathematical adjustment to the DELAY function that is necessary to preserve the mass-balance.

Editors: A Kyprianou, W Schoutens, P Wilmott
OtherDetails:
The book ?Exotic Option Pricing and Advanced Levy Models? (eds.: A. Kyprianou, W. Schoutens and P. Wilmott) is a collection of cutting-edge research papers on the use of Levy processes as a mathematical tool in modelling exotic options. It consists of a compendium of refereed articles by a number of leading international researchers (including Geman, Madan, Eberlein, Peskir and Carr).

The contribution by Chan, ?Pricing perpetual American options driven by spectrally positive Levy processes?, was at the special request of the editors, because in their opinion, ?many important features of the perpetual American put pricing problem are observed?. To paraphrase one of the referees, it was among the first papers to observe the central role played by the so-called ?smooth-pasting? property in models of put options driven by Levy processes. This property has since been shown by others to play a central role in optimal stopping problems generally. In the context of put option pricing, the phenomenon of smooth-pasting was first observed by Samuelson in the 60s; more recently Gerber and Shiu, in a series of papers published in the late 90s have used this property to solve the problem of pricing a perpetual put on an asset whose price is driven by a jump-diffusion process. The paper by Chan extends the results of Gerber and Shiu by establishing smooth-pasting at the optimal exercise level for a perpetual put on an asset whose price is driven by a general spectrally-one-sided Levy process.

OtherDetails:
The "gnm" package is the culmination of extensive methodological research on approximate inference, computation and the effective summarization of results, for a class of models --- the "generalized nonlinear models" ---  which unifies many widely used nonlinear methods of analysis from research fields such as sociology, psychology, political science, actuarial science, demography, crop science and medicine.  A 50-page manual is included with the package, giving an overview and a variety of examples.  Particular innovations in gnm include the development of tools for working routinely with over-parameterized representations of models --- specifically, generalized iterative algorithms and tools for the extraction, checking and presentation of inferences on validly interpretable parameter combinations.  The resulting package, published with full documentation through the open-source R project, allows researchers, especially those working in other disciplines, both to draw valid inferences (in many cases not available through other software) from their "standard" analyses, and to work easily with more general analyses suggested by the interactive approach to model-building and model criticism which gnm encourages.  

In 2007 the innovations and design of gnm led to its winning the John M Chambers Statistical Software Award of the American Statistical Association.

Initial public release of gnm to CRAN (the Comprehensive R Archive Network)

LongTitle: Bayes Linear Statistics: Theory and Methods.
OtherDetails: This book unifies and extends work carried out by the authors dating back to 1984, and earlier by the first author alone.  About one third of the material is new to this volume. All of the earlier work has been re-examined and adapted to provide a coherent and consistent development of the theory. The book covers the foundations, theory, methodology, mathematics and practicalities of the Bayes linear approach. It explains the main ideas, gives the important results and illustrates with practical examples. The book starts with a development of the basic language of Bayes linear analysis, describing the fundamental operations of belief adjustment and partial adjustment, the interpretation of such adjustments using belief transforms and the diagnostics for comparing beliefs with observation based on the bearing and the data trajectory.  We give a careful description of the role of exchangeability, which is fundamental to our approach in allowing us to create statistical models purely in terms of predictive statements over observables. We then discuss more general ways of analysing beliefs through generalised belief transforms, illustrated with statistical examples of various degrees of complexity. We develop methods for learning about variances and correlations from a Bayes linear perspective. We provide a general theory for comparison of alternative belief specifications for exchangeable multivariate samples, and graphical procedures to highlight the essential features of the analysis. We discuss the twin roles of Bayes linear graphical models, in representing both the qualitative structure and the quantitative effects of a Bayes linear analysis. We conclude by constructing all of the algebraic results that are needed for efficient implementation of the Bayes linear approach.

LongTitle: Bayesian integrated functional analysis of microarray data
OtherDetails: Procedures for testing trends in the intensity functions of nonhomogeneous Poisson processes are based mostly on conditioning on the number of failures observed in (0, t] with fixed t. We study an unconditional test based on the time-truncated data that enables meaningful asymptotics as t becomes large. We show that the asymptotic test is conservative and that its power quickly comes close to the power of the uniformly most powerful unbiased test for the power-law alternatives. Moreover, for the goodness of fit of a specified intensity, the exact test has more power than the test based on the conditional approach. We illustrate the procedure using a real dataset.

LongTitle: Bayesian association-based fine mapping in small chromosomal segments
OtherDetails: A Bayesian method for fine mapping is presented, which deals with multiallelic markers, unknown phase, missing data, multiple causal variants, and both continuous and binary phenotypes. We consider small chromosomal segments spanned by a dense set of closely linked markers and putative genes only at marker points. In the phenotypic model, locus-specific indicator variables are used to control inclusion in or exclusion from marker contributions. To account for covariance between consecutive loci and to control fluctuations in association signals along a candidate region, we introduce a joint prior for the indicators that depends on genetic or physical map distances. The potential of the method includes posterior estimation of trait-associated loci, their effects, linkage disequilibrium pattern due to close linkage of loci, and the age of a causal variant (time to most recent common ancestor). Estimation of model parameters is based on Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) sampling and is implemented using WinBUGS. Cited in Genetics, Theoretical and Applied Genetics, PLoS genetics, book chapter. Software has been downloaded numerous times.

LongTitle: Spatially Explicit Maximum Likelihood Methods for Capture-Recapture Studies

The full range of existing likelihood-based mark-recapture models is generalised to include a spatial component in the capture function - without which estimation of effective capture area and hence density is essentially ad hoc.

LongTitle: Prior Induction in Log-Linear Models for General Contingency Table Analysis

In particular we derive an explicit expression for the induced prior on the multinomial cell probabilities, given a multivariate Normal prior specification on the log-linear parameters, for any log-linear model and discuss the importance of these results in terms of both uninformative and informative priors.

LongTitle: Bayesian Model Discrimination for Multiple Strata Capture-Recapture Data.

A Bayesian approach is implemented and a reversible jump Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm developed to explore the complex and large model space. Particular issues are addressed including the specification of consistent (informative) prior distributions for parameters across models, the construction of biologically plausible models to be considered, and efficient updating algorithms.

LongTitle: Unconditional tests of goodness of fit for the intensity of time-truncated nonhomogeneous Poisson processes
OtherDetails: This paper presents a novel method of modelling microarray data. Although there is a large literature for analysing microarray data, almost all methods deal with only one step of analysis. This lack of consideration for propagation of error in decision making has been known to lead to disastrous results. Here we show that, by an application of hierarchical Bayesian methodology, this sequential procedure can be replaced by a single joint analysis, while systematically accounting for the uncertainties in this process. This modelling framework additionally allows inference based on data from wide range of sources. Cited in: Biometrics, Bioinformatics, BMC Bioinformatics, Briefings in Bioinformatics (Impact factor 24.37), Comparative and Functional Genomics, Theoretical and Applied Genetics, Drug Discovery Today.

OtherDetails: This paper focuses on incorporating all the available information within the analysis of complex multi-state capture-recapture data and discriminating between competing biological hypotheses. In particular, the catch-effort information is modelled explicitly and a Trans-dimensional Simulated Annealing algorithm developed to discriminate between the large number of competing models, using the AIC statistic as the underlying model selection criterion.

LongTitle: Association mapping of complex trait loci with context-dependent effects and unknown context variable
OtherDetails: A novel method for Bayesian analysis of genetic heterogeneity and multilocus association in random population samples is presented. The method is valid for quantitative and binary traits as well as for multiallelic markers. In the method, individuals are stochastically assigned into two etiological groups that can have both their own, and possibly different, subsets of trait-associated loci or alleles. The method is favorable especially in situations when etiological models are stratified by the factors that are unknown or went unmeasured, that is, if genetic heterogeneity is due to, for example, unknown genes by environment or gene by gene interactions. Additionally, a heterogeneity structure for the phenotype does not need to follow the structure of the general population; it can have a distinct selection history. The performance of the method is illustrated with a simulated example of genes by environment interaction and compared to the results of single-group analysis in the presence of missing data. Additionally, example analyses with previously analysed cystic fibrosis and type 2 diabetes data sets are presented. Cited in Genetics as Issue Highlights, core scientific literature on cystic fibrosis, Genomics & Genetics Weekly. Software has been downloaded numerous times.

LongTitle: Embedding population dynamics models in inference.
OtherDetails: This paper reviews recent developments to allow population dynamics models to be embedded in inference. It also explains the building-block approach for matrix population models first proposed by Buckland et al. in an Ecological Modelling paper, and shows how to extend these, using compositions of random non-linear operators, to a more general and fully stochastic framework.

LongTitle: Factors Influencing Soay Sheep Survival: A Bayesian Analysis
OtherDetails: Within the analysis of complex ecological data, interest often lies in determining the underlying factors that drive the system. We consider in detail the mark-recapture-recovery data of a particular dataset (Soay sheep), in the presence of environmental and individual covariates (including missing covariate values for many individuals). A reversible jump Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm is constructed that explores the extremely complex model space, where there is uncertainty in the age-structure of the demographic parameters of interest, in addition to covariate dependence and random effects. Interesting features are identified which had not previously been detected and which are of ecological importance.

LongTitle: State-space models for the dynamics of wild animal populations
OtherDetails: This was the first of a series of papers expounding a building-block approach to matrix population models, which allows complex, fully stochastic models to be specified simply. Fitting of the models was addressed briefly, with follow-up papers by Newman et al, Biometrics, submitted, Buckland et al, Stat Sci, 2007, Newman et al, Ecol Applications, 2006, Thomas et al, ANZJS, 2005. The impact of this paper is indicated by the fact that, by August 2007, 23 papers in refereed journals had cited it.

LongTitle: Monitoring change in biodiversity through composite indices
Publisher: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London Series B
OtherDetails: This paper addresses statistical issues in monitoring regional biodiversity trends, which have largely been ignored. There is now much interest in this, due to the 2010 target to "reduce the rate of loss of biodiversity by 2010", which nearly 200 countries have signed up to. The paper has attracted a lot of interest, which led to an invitation for Buckland to teach at a biodiversity monitoring workshop in Brazil in June 2007. The paper had been cited by 13 papers in refereed journals by August 2007.

LongTitle: Distance 5.0 Release 2
Publisher: Research Unit for Wildlife Population Assessment, University of St Andrews
OtherDetails: The Distance software is one of the most widely used pieces of research output in statistical ecology worldwide, and a first-class example of knowledge transfer from a UK research institution to a global user community. Since 1998, it has been registered from over 13,000 unique email addresses in more than 120 countries. Typing the generic word "distance" into Google consistently brings up the software home page in the top three returns. The software allows users (primarily biologists) to design and analyse surveys to estimate the size of wildlife populations, using distance sampling methods. Distance sampling is one of the main research focuses of the statistical ecology group at St Andrews, and new methods developed by PhD students, research and academic staff are routinely incorporated into new versions of Distance, further extending the range and reliability of the methods. Recent versions of the software have added, for example: a built-in GIS with new algorithms for automated survey design (PhD work by Strindberg); methods that combine distance sampling and mark-recapture (papers by Borchers and others) implemented via a link to a new R library; methods for spatial density surface fitting (currently beta software; PhD work by Hedley, and other research). Feedback from users often inspires further research avenues, and on many occasions has led to funding for collaborative research projects, such as a recent US$1.5million award to develop methods for estimating population densities of sea mammals from undersea hydrophones.

LongTitle: Advanced Distance Sampling
OtherDetails: This book introduces a number of innovations in distance sampling. It is an edited volume, with 11 chapters. Buckland is co-author on 8 of these chapters. Innovations co-authored by Buckland include further elaboration of the covariate methods of Marques and Buckland (2003), extending the methods of Hedley and Buckland (2004) to point transect sampling, developing methods for estimating trends in time, adaptive distance sampling methods well beyond those described by Pollard, Palka and Buckland (2002), development of automated design algorithms that have much wider applicability than those of Strindberg and Buckland (2004), elaborating the design-based and model-based methods underlying distance sampling and developing a general framework for testing the robustness of the methods, and a new mathematical proof of the pooling robustness property of distance sampling estimators.

LongTitle: Accommodating unmodeled heterogeneity in double-observer distance sampling surveys
OtherDetails: A key paper in the development of mark-recapture distance sampling methodologies, providing methods that perform well even in the presence of unmodelled heterogeneity.

LongTitle: Modelling establishment probabilities of an exotic plant, Rhododendron ponticum, invading a heterogeneous, woodland landscape using logistic regression with spatial autocorrelation
OtherDetails: This paper models establishment probabilities using a Generalized Linear Model with spatially auto-correlated errors. Model outcomes, and the recommended management practices, differ when the autocorrelation is considered. The paper is aimed at scientists who routinely ignore residual autocorrelation but are looking for an alternative approach.

LongTitle: Regression Spline Mixed Models: a forestry example
Publisher: Journal of Agricultural, Biological and Environmental Statistics
OtherDetails: This paper uses biological information to specify regression spline mixed models and contrasts this manual specification with an automated knot selection procedure and nonlinear mixed model alternatives. It also compares the performance of the nonparametric bootstrap (carried out with and without knot uncertainty) with model based and robust model inference. This paper adds value to this area by highlighting how biological information can be used to specify parsimonious models which return superior model fit and examines the performance of the nonparametric bootstrap for mixed model data.

LongTitle: Line Transect Methods for Plant Surveys
OtherDetails: This paper provides a hierarchy of methods for extending distance sampling techniques to deal with special circumstances often associated with surveys of plants. The methods range from simple strip transect sampling to double-observer mark-recapture distance sampling with non-uniform distribution of objects wrt to the line. Circumstances covered include small study areas, highly clustered populations and extreme heterogeneity in detectability of individuals. We anticipate that this paper will lead to much improved population assessments for many species of vascular plant of conservation concern.

Sampling distributions associated with the multivariate t distribution
OtherDetails:
Multivariate t distributions are of increasing importance in classical as well as in Bayesian statistical modelling; however, relatively little is known by means of mathematical properties or statistical methods. These distributions have been perhaps unjustly overshadowed by the multivariate normal distribution.  In this paper, we provide a comprehensive review of sampling distributions of certain statistics associated with multivariate t distributions.  The topics reviewed include: Wishart matrix, multivariate t statistic, Hotelling's T^2 statistic, entropy and Kullback-Leibler number.  The known simulation methods are also reviewed. We believe that this review could serve as an important reference and encourage further research activities espeically because multivariate t distributions offer a more viable alternative to multivariate normal distributions with respect to real-world data. We have already seen some unexpected applications in novel areas such 
as cluster analysis, discriminant analysis, multiple regression, robust projection indices, and missing data imputation.

The paper has been ranked among the 10 most read articles published by the journal, Statistica Neeraladica.

EnglishAbstract:
We consider the accumulation of beneficial and deleterious mutations in large asexual populations. The rate of adaptation is affected by the total mutation
rate, proportion of beneficial mutations, and population size $N$. We show that regardless of mutation rates, as long as the proportion of beneficial mutations is strictly positive, the adaptation rate is at least O(log^{1-\delta} N), if the population size is sufficiently large. This shows that if the genome is modelled as continuous, there is no limit to natural selection.
